title: 114_hr4696
content: The Act titled "Helping Our Middle-Income Earners Act" or the "HOME Act" introduces a new section for the deduction of homeowners association assessments in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The HOME Act introduces a deduction for qualified homeowners association assessments paid by an individual during the taxable year. The deduction is limited to $5,000, with a reduction based on modified adjusted gross income. The HOME Act introduces a deduction for qualified homeowners association assessments paid by an individual during the taxable year. The deduction is limited to $5,000, with a reduction based on modified adjusted gross income, which is the taxpayer's adjusted gross income for the year increased by any excluded amounts. For taxable years starting after 2016, dollar amounts in subparagraph (B)(i)(II) will increase based on the cost-of-living adjustment determined for the calendar year, using 2015 as the base year for calculations. For taxable years after 2016, dollar amounts are adjusted to the nearest lower multiple of $500. Qualified homeowners association assessments refer to regular financial payments benefiting the taxpayer's principal residence. The taxpayer's mandatory membership in a homeowners association is defined in section 528(c)(1) without including timeshare associations. Information reporting requirements for homeowners association assessments are amended in the tax code. "SEC. 6050X. RETURNS RELATED TO HOMEOWNERS ASSOCIATION ASSESSMENTS." "Any homeowners association receiving qualified homeowners association assessments must file a return with the name, address, and TIN of each individual and the amount of assessments received. They must also provide a written statement to each individual with the contact information and required information." The homeowners association must provide a written statement to individuals by January 31 of the following year, detailing the required information. The deduction for homeowners association assessments is not considered a miscellaneous itemized deduction. The homeowners association assessments deduction is not considered a miscellaneous itemized deduction. The table of sections for Part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Code is amended. The amendments made by this section regarding homeowners association assessments shall apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2015.
